articles.headline: Fake Russian Facebook Accounts Bought $100,000 in Political Ads
articles.snippet: Facebook said that fake accounts and pages had bought 3,000 ads focused on divisive social issues, including race and immigration.
articles.abstract: Facebook said that fake accounts and pages had bought 3,000 ads focused on divisive social issues, including race and immigration.
articles.lead_paragraph: Providing new evidence of Russian interference in the 2016 election, Facebook disclosed on Wednesday that it had identified more than $100,000 worth of divisive ads on hot-button issues purchased by a shadowy Russian company linked to the Kremlin.
articles.byline: By Scott Shane and Vindu Goel

articles.headline: Democrats Begin Legal Assault on Trump’s Move to End ‘Dreamer’ Program
articles.snippet: A group of 16 Democratic attorneys general have filed suit in New York, claiming that Mr. Trump had improperly upended the policy known as Deferred Action for Childhood Arrivals.
articles.abstract: A group of 16 Democratic attorneys general have filed suit in New York, claiming that Mr. Trump had improperly upended the policy known as Deferred Action for Childhood Arrivals.
articles.lead_paragraph: President Trump’s immigration policies faced a renewed legal onslaught on Wednesday, as a coalition of Democratic attorneys general, nonprofit groups and private companies announced they would oppose his rollback of Obama-era protections for people who entered the country illegally as children.
articles.byline: By Alexander Burns and Vivian Yee

articles.headline: Hurricane Irma, One of the Most Powerful in History, Roars Across Caribbean
articles.snippet: The storm left wreckage and flooding on Caribbean islands and is making its way toward Florida.
articles.abstract: The storm left wreckage and flooding on Caribbean islands and is making its way toward Florida.
articles.lead_paragraph: This is an overview of Hurricane Irma, reported by journalists throughout the region. To see their latest dispatches from places hit by the storm, go to Thursday's live Irma updates.
articles.byline: By Frances Robles, Kirk Semple and Richard Pérez-Peña

articles.headline: European Central Bank Signals End of Cheap Money Era is Coming
articles.snippet: The bank’s policy setting committee had a preliminary discussion about withdrawing its enormous stimulus program, its president, Mario Draghi, said.
articles.abstract: The bank’s policy setting committee had a preliminary discussion about withdrawing its enormous stimulus program, its president, Mario Draghi, said.
articles.lead_paragraph: FRANKFURT — Europe has taken a small step in its long march toward economic normalcy.

articles.headline: Attacked by Rotten Tomatoes
articles.snippet: Hollywood says the website and its increasingly ubiquitous Tomatometer scores are hurting ticket sales. The site’s editors say they are simply helping moviegoers.
articles.abstract: Hollywood says the website and its increasingly ubiquitous Tomatometer scores are hurting ticket sales. The site’s editors say they are simply helping moviegoers.
articles.lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — Hollywood had a horrible summer.

articles.headline: Trump Jr. Says He Wanted Russian Dirt to Determine Clinton’s ‘Fitness’ for Office
articles.snippet: Investigators believe the president’s son is crucial to understanding a June 2016 meeting between the Trump inner circle and a Kremlin-connected lawyer.
articles.abstract: Investigators believe the president’s son is crucial to understanding a June 2016 meeting between the Trump inner circle and a Kremlin-connected lawyer.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Donald Trump Jr. told Senate investigators on Thursday that he set up a June 2016 meeting with a Russian lawyer because he was intrigued that she might have damaging information about Hillary Clinton, saying it was important to learn about Mrs. Clinton’s “fitness” to be president.
articles.byline: By Nicholas Fandos and Maggie Haberman

articles.headline: Amazon Plans Second Headquarters, Opening a Bidding War Among Cities
articles.snippet: The online retail giant said it is seeking a location in North America for a new complex that would cost as much as $5 billion to build and operate.
articles.abstract: The online retail giant said it is seeking a location in North America for a new complex that would cost as much as $5 billion to build and operate.
articles.lead_paragraph: SEATTLE — Wanted: A place with a million people, a diverse population, good schools and malleable lawmakers. Room to accommodate up to 50,000 workers. Canadian provinces also welcome to apply.
articles.byline: By Nick Wingfield and Patricia Cohen

articles.headline: Law Firm Sees Britain as Hunting Ground for U.S. Whistle-Blower Cases
articles.snippet: Its lawyers say that United States laws offering rewards for exposing corporate misdeeds present a business opportunity.
articles.abstract: Its lawyers say that United States laws offering rewards for exposing corporate misdeeds present a business opportunity.
articles.lead_paragraph: LONDON — When federal prosecutors recently charged a little-known British luxury knitwear company with evading custom duties, few knew the role a small New York law firm played in the case.

articles.headline: Energized Trump Sees Bipartisan Path, at Least for Now
articles.snippet: A day after reaching a fiscal deal with Democrats, the president waged peace with the opposition party in hopes of finding more areas of agreement.
articles.abstract: A day after reaching a fiscal deal with Democrats, the president waged peace with the opposition party in hopes of finding more areas of agreement.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — By the time President Trump woke up on Thursday morning, he was feeling upbeat. And as he watched television news reports about his fiscal agreement with Democrats, he felt like telling someone.
articles.byline: By Peter Baker and Sheryl Gay Stolberg

articles.headline: Graydon Carter to End 25-Year Run as Vanity Fair’s Editor
articles.snippet: When he steps down in December, Mr. Carter will leave the role that established him as a celebrity in his own right and a ringmaster of the spheres of Hollywood, Washington and Manhattan media.
articles.abstract: When he steps down in December, Mr. Carter will leave the role that established him as a celebrity in his own right and a ringmaster of the spheres of Hollywood, Washington and Manhattan media.
articles.lead_paragraph: Graydon Carter, the editor of Vanity Fair, plans to step down from the magazine in December after a 25-year tenure, leaving the role that established him as a ringmaster of the Hollywood, Washington and Manhattan power elite.
